member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.AddTagsToResourceRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the AddTagsToResource operation. Adds or overwrites one or more tags for the specified resource. Tags are metadata that you can assign to your documents, managed instances, maintenance windows, Parameter Store parameters, and patch baselines. Tags enable you to categorize your resources in different ways, for example, by purpose, owner, or environment. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, both of which you define. For example, you could define a set of tags for your account's managed instances that helps you track each instance's owner and stack level. For example: Key=Owner and Value=DbAdmin, SysAdmin, or Dev. Or Key=Stack and Value=Production, Pre-Production, or Test.
Each resource can have a maximum of 50 tags.
We recommend that you devise a set of tag keys that meets your needs for each resource type. Using a consistent set of tag keys makes it easier for you to manage your resources. You can search and filter the resources based on the tags you add. Tags don't have any semantic meaning to Amazon EC2 and are interpreted strictly as a string of characters.
For more information about tags, see Tagging Your Amazon EC2 Resources in the Amazon EC2 User Guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.AddTagsToResourceRequest.ResourceId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ResourceId.
The resource ID you want to tag.
Use the ID of the resource. Here are some examples:
ManagedInstance: mi-012345abcde
MaintenanceWindow: mw-012345abcde
PatchBaseline: pb-012345abcde
For the Document and Parameter values, use the name of the resource.
The ManagedInstance type for this API action is only for on-premises managed instances. You must specify the name of the managed instance in the following format: mi-ID_number. For example, mi-1a2b3c4d5e6f.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.AddTagsToResourceRequest.ResourceType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ResourceType.
Specifies the type of resource you are tagging.
The ManagedInstance type for this API action is for on-premises managed instances. You must specify the name of the managed instance in the following format: mi-ID_number. For example, mi-1a2b3c4d5e6f.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.AddTagsToResourceRequest.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
One or more tags. The value parameter is required, but if you don't want the tag to have a value, specify the parameter with no value, and we set the value to an empty string.
Do not enter personally identifiable information in this field.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.AssociationDescription.MaxConcurrency
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxConcurrency.
The maximum number of targets allowed to run the association at the same time. You can specify a number, for example 10, or a percentage of the target set, for example 10%. The default value is 100%, which means all targets run the association at the same time.
If a new instance starts and attempts to run an association while Systems Manager is running MaxConcurrency associations, the association is allowed to run. During the next association interval, the new instance will process its association within the limit specified for MaxConcurrency.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.AssociationDescription.MaxErrors
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxErrors.
The number of errors that are allowed before the system stops sending requests to run the association on additional targets. You can specify either an absolute number of errors, for example 10, or a percentage of the target set, for example 10%. If you specify 3, for example, the system stops sending requests when the fourth error is received. If you specify 0, then the system stops sending requests after the first error is returned. If you run an association on 50 instances and set MaxError to 10%, then the system stops sending the request when the sixth error is received.
Executions that are already running an association when MaxErrors is reached are allowed to complete, but some of these executions may fail as well. If you need to ensure that there won't be more than max-errors failed executions, set MaxConcurrency to 1 so that executions proceed one at a time.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.AssociationVersionInfo.MaxErrors
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxErrors.
The number of errors that are allowed before the system stops sending requests to run the association on additional targets. You can specify either an absolute number of errors, for example 10, or a percentage of the target set, for example 10%. If you specify 3, for example, the system stops sending requests when the fourth error is received. If you specify 0, then the system stops sending requests after the first error is returned. If you run an association on 50 instances and set MaxError to 10%, then the system stops sending the request when the sixth error is received.
Executions that are already running an association when MaxErrors is reached are allowed to complete, but some of these executions may fail as well. If you need to ensure that there won't be more than max-errors failed executions, set MaxConcurrency to 1 so that executions proceed one at a time.

The name specified when the association was created.

member.summary:

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.Command.InstanceIds
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InstanceIds.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.Command.MaxConcurrency
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxConcurrency.
The maximum number of instances that are allowed to run the command at the same time. You can specify a number of instances, such as 10, or a percentage of instances, such as 10%. The default value is 50. For more information about how to use MaxConcurrency, see Running Commands Using Systems Manager Run Command in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.Command.MaxErrors
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxErrors.
The maximum number of errors allowed before the system stops sending the command to additional targets. You can specify a number of errors, such as 10, or a percentage or errors, such as 10%. The default value is 0. For more information about how to use MaxErrors, see Running Commands Using Systems Manager Run Command in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide.

The IAM service role that Run Command uses to act on your behalf when sending notifications about command status changes.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.Command.Status
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Status.
The status of the command.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.Command.StatusDetails
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property StatusDetails.
A detailed status of the command execution. StatusDetails includes more information than Status because it includes states resulting from error and concurrency control parameters. StatusDetails can show different results than Status. For more information about these statuses, see Understanding Command Statuses in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide. StatusDetails can be one of the following values:
Pending: The command has not been sent to any instances.
In Progress: The command has been sent to at least one instance but has not reached a final state on all instances.
Success: The command successfully ran on all invocations. This is a terminal state.
Delivery Timed Out: The value of MaxErrors or more command invocations shows a status of Delivery Timed Out. This is a terminal state.
Execution Timed Out: The value of MaxErrors or more command invocations shows a status of Execution Timed Out. This is a terminal state.
Failed: The value of MaxErrors or more command invocations shows a status of Failed. This is a terminal state.
Incomplete: The command was attempted on all instances and one or more invocations does not have a value of Success but not enough invocations failed for the status to be Failed. This is a terminal state.
Canceled: The command was terminated before it was completed. This is a terminal state.
Rate Exceeded: The number of instances targeted by the command exceeded the account limit for pending invocations. The system has canceled the command before running it on any instance. This is a terminal state.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.Command.TargetCount
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TargetCount.
The number of targets for the command.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.Command.Targets
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Targets.
An array of search criteria that targets instances using a Key,Value combination that you specify. Targets is required if you don't provide one or more instance IDs in the call.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CommandFilter
member.summary: Describes a command filter.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CommandFilter.Key
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Key.
The name of the filter.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CommandFilter.Value
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Value.
The filter value. Valid values for each filter key are as follows:
InvokedAfter: Specify a timestamp to limit your results. For example, specify 2018-07-07T00:00:00Z to see a list of command executions occurring July 7, 2018, and later.
InvokedBefore: Specify a timestamp to limit your results. For example, specify 2018-07-07T00:00:00Z to see a list of command executions from before July 7, 2018.
Status: Specify a valid command status to see a list of all command executions with that status. Status values you can specify include:
Pending
InProgress
Success
Cancelled
Failed
TimedOut
Cancelling
DocumentName: Specify name of the SSM document for which you want to see command execution results. For example, specify AWS-RunPatchBaseline to see command executions that used this SSM document to perform security patching operations on instances.
ExecutionStage: Specify one of the following values:
Executing: Returns a list of command executions that are currently still running.
Complete: Returns a list of command executions that have already completed.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CommandInvocation.Status
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Status.
Whether or not the invocation succeeded, failed, or is pending.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CommandInvocation.StatusDetails
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property StatusDetails.
A detailed status of the command execution for each invocation (each instance targeted by the command). StatusDetails includes more information than Status because it includes states resulting from error and concurrency control parameters. StatusDetails can show different results than Status. For more information about these statuses, see Understanding Command Statuses in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide. StatusDetails can be one of the following values:
Pending: The command has not been sent to the instance.
In Progress: The command has been sent to the instance but has not reached a terminal state.
Success: The execution of the command or plugin was successfully completed. This is a terminal state.
Delivery Timed Out: The command was not delivered to the instance before the delivery timeout expired. Delivery timeouts do not count against the parent command's MaxErrors limit, but they do contribute to whether the parent command status is Success or Incomplete. This is a terminal state.
Execution Timed Out: Command execution started on the instance, but the execution was not complete before the execution timeout expired. Execution timeouts count against the MaxErrors limit of the parent command. This is a terminal state.
Failed: The command was not successful on the instance. For a plugin, this indicates that the result code was not zero. For a command invocation, this indicates that the result code for one or more plugins was not zero. Invocation failures count against the MaxErrors limit of the parent command. This is a terminal state.
Canceled: The command was terminated before it was completed. This is a terminal state.
Undeliverable: The command can't be delivered to the instance. The instance might not exist or might not be responding. Undeliverable invocations don't count against the parent command's MaxErrors limit and don't contribute to whether the parent command status is Success or Incomplete. This is a terminal state.
Terminated: The parent command exceeded its MaxErrors limit and subsequent command invocations were canceled by the system. This is a terminal state.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CommandInvocation.TraceOutput
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TraceOutput.
Gets the trace output sent by the agent.

StatusDetails can show different results than Status. For more information about these statuses, see Understanding Command Statuses in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide. StatusDetails can be one of the following values:
Pending: The command has not been sent to the instance.
In Progress: The command has been sent to the instance but has not reached a terminal state.
Success: The execution of the command or plugin was successfully completed. This is a terminal state.
Delivery Timed Out: The command was not delivered to the instance before the delivery timeout expired. Delivery timeouts do not count against the parent command's MaxErrors limit, but they do contribute to whether the parent command status is Success or Incomplete. This is a terminal state.
Execution Timed Out: Command execution started on the instance, but the execution was not complete before the execution timeout expired. Execution timeouts count against the MaxErrors limit of the parent command. This is a terminal state.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateActivationRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the CreateActivation operation. Registers your on-premises server or virtual machine with Amazon EC2 so that you can manage these resources using Run Command. An on-premises server or virtual machine that has been registered with EC2 is called a managed instance. For more information about activations, see Setting Up AWS Systems Manager for Hybrid Environments.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateActivationRequest.DefaultInstanceName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property DefaultInstanceName.
The name of the registered, managed instance as it will appear in the Amazon EC2 console or when you use the AWS command line tools to list EC2 resources.
Do not enter personally identifiable information in this field.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateActivationRequest.Description
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Description.
A user-defined description of the resource that you want to register with Amazon EC2.
Do not enter personally identifiable information in this field.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateActivationRequest.ExpirationDate
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExpirationDate.
The date by which this activation request should expire. The default value is 24 hours.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateActivationRequest.IamRole
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property IamRole.
The Amazon Identity and Access Management (IAM) role that you want to assign to the managed instance.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateActivationRequest.RegistrationLimit
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RegistrationLimit.
Specify the maximum number of managed instances you want to register. The default value is 1 instance.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateActivationRequest.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
Optional metadata that you assign to a resource. Tags enable you to categorize a resource in different ways, such as by purpose, owner, or environment. For example, you might want to tag an activation to identify which servers or virtual machines (VMs) in your on-premises environment you intend to activate. In this case, you could specify the following key name/value pairs:
Key=OS,Value=Windows
Key=Environment,Value=Production
When you install SSM Agent on your on-premises servers and VMs, you specify an activation ID and code. When you specify the activation ID and code, tags assigned to the activation are automatically applied to the on-premises servers or VMs.
You can't add tags to or delete tags from an existing activation. You can tag your on-premises servers and VMs after they connect to Systems Manager for the first time and are assigned a managed instance ID. This means they are listed in the AWS Systems Manager console with an ID that is prefixed with "mi-". For information about how to add tags to your managed instances, see AddTagsToResource. For information about how to remove tags from your managed instances, see RemoveTagsFromResource.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateActivationResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the CreateActivation operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateActivationResponse.ActivationCode
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ActivationCode.
The code the system generates when it processes the activation. The activation code functions like a password to validate the activation ID.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateActivationResponse.ActivationId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ActivationId.
The ID number generated by the system when it processed the activation. The activation ID functions like a user name.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationBatchRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the CreateAssociationBatch operation. Associates the specified Systems Manager document with the specified instances or targets.
When you associate a document with one or more instances using instance IDs or tags, SSM Agent running on the instance processes the document and configures the instance as specified.
If you associate a document with an instance that already has an associated document, the system returns the AssociationAlreadyExists exception.

member.name: M:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationBatchRequest.#ctor
member.summary: Empty constructor used to set properties independently even when a simple constructor is available

member.name: M:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationBatchRequest.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.List{Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationBatchRequestEntry})
member.summary: Instantiates CreateAssociationBatchRequest with the parameterized properties
member.param: One or more associations.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationBatchRequest.Entries
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Entries.
One or more associations.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationBatchRequestEntry
member.summary: Describes the association of a Systems Manager SSM document and an instance.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationBatchRequestEntry.AssociationName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AssociationName.
Specify a descriptive name for the association.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationBatchRequestEntry.AutomationTargetParameterName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AutomationTargetParameterName.
Specify the target for the association. This target is required for associations that use an Automation document and target resources by using rate controls.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationBatchRequestEntry.ComplianceSeverity
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ComplianceSeverity.
The severity level to assign to the association.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationBatchRequestEntry.DocumentVersion
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property DocumentVersion.
The document version.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationBatchRequestEntry.InstanceId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InstanceId.
The ID of the instance.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationBatchRequestEntry.MaxConcurrency
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxConcurrency.
The maximum number of targets allowed to run the association at the same time. You can specify a number, for example 10, or a percentage of the target set, for example 10%. The default value is 100%, which means all targets run the association at the same time.
If a new instance starts and attempts to run an association while Systems Manager is running MaxConcurrency associations, the association is allowed to run. During the next association interval, the new instance will process its association within the limit specified for MaxConcurrency.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationBatchRequestEntry.MaxErrors
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxErrors.
The number of errors that are allowed before the system stops sending requests to run the association on additional targets. You can specify either an absolute number of errors, for example 10, or a percentage of the target set, for example 10%. If you specify 3, for example, the system stops sending requests when the fourth error is received. If you specify 0, then the system stops sending requests after the first error is returned. If you run an association on 50 instances and set MaxError to 10%, then the system stops sending the request when the sixth error is received.
Executions that are already running an association when MaxErrors is reached are allowed to complete, but some of these executions may fail as well. If you need to ensure that there won't be more than max-errors failed executions, set MaxConcurrency to 1 so that executions proceed one at a time.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationBatchRequestEntry.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The name of the SSM document that contains the configuration information for the instance. You can specify Command or Automation documents.
You can specify AWS-predefined documents, documents you created, or a document that is shared with you from another account.
For SSM documents that are shared with you from other AWS accounts, you must specify the complete SSM document ARN, in the following format:
arn:aws:ssm:region:account-id:document/document-name
For example:
arn:aws:ssm:us-east-2:12345678912:document/My-Shared-Document
For AWS-predefined documents and SSM documents you created in your account, you only need to specify the document name. For example, AWS-ApplyPatchBaseline or My-Document.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationBatchRequestEntry.OutputLocation
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OutputLocation.
An Amazon S3 bucket where you want to store the results of this request.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationBatchRequestEntry.Parameters

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the CreateAssociation operation. Associates the specified Systems Manager document with the specified instances or targets.
When you associate a document with one or more instances using instance IDs or tags, SSM Agent running on the instance processes the document and configures the instance as specified.
If you associate a document with an instance that already has an associated document, the system returns the AssociationAlreadyExists exception.

member.name: M:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationRequest.#ctor
member.summary: Empty constructor used to set properties independently even when a simple constructor is available

member.name: M:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationRequest.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Instantiates CreateAssociationRequest with the parameterized properties
member.param: The instance ID. InstanceId has been deprecated. To specify an instance ID for an association, use the Targets parameter. If you use the parameter InstanceId, you cannot use the parameters AssociationName, DocumentVersion, MaxErrors, MaxConcurrency, OutputLocation, or ScheduleExpression. To use these parameters, you must use the Targets parameter.

The name of the SSM document that contains the configuration information for the instance. You can specify Command or Automation documents. You can specify AWS-predefined documents, documents you created, or a document that is shared with you from another account. For SSM documents that are shared with you from other AWS accounts, you must specify the complete SSM document ARN, in the following format: arn:partition:ssm:region:account-id:document/document-name For example: arn:aws:ssm:us-east-2:12345678912:document/My-Shared-Document For AWS-predefined documents and SSM documents you created in your account, you only need to specify the document name. For example, AWS-ApplyPatchBaseline or My-Document.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationRequest.AssociationName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AssociationName.
Specify a descriptive name for the association.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationRequest.AutomationTargetParameterName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AutomationTargetParameterName.
Specify the target for the association. This target is required for associations that use an Automation document and target resources by using rate controls.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationRequest.ComplianceSeverity
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ComplianceSeverity.
The severity level to assign to the association.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationRequest.DocumentVersion
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property DocumentVersion.
The document version you want to associate with the target(s). Can be a specific version or the default version.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationRequest.InstanceId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InstanceId.
The instance ID.
InstanceId has been deprecated. To specify an instance ID for an association, use the Targets parameter. If you use the parameter InstanceId, you cannot use the parameters AssociationName, DocumentVersion, MaxErrors, MaxConcurrency, OutputLocation, or ScheduleExpression. To use these parameters, you must use the Targets parameter.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationRequest.MaxConcurrency
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxConcurrency.
The maximum number of targets allowed to run the association at the same time. You can specify a number, for example 10, or a percentage of the target set, for example 10%. The default value is 100%, which means all targets run the association at the same time.
If a new instance starts and attempts to run an association while Systems Manager is running MaxConcurrency associations, the association is allowed to run. During the next association interval, the new instance will process its association within the limit specified for MaxConcurrency.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationRequest.MaxErrors
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MaxErrors.
The number of errors that are allowed before the system stops sending requests to run the association on additional targets. You can specify either an absolute number of errors, for example 10, or a percentage of the target set, for example 10%. If you specify 3, for example, the system stops sending requests when the fourth error is received. If you specify 0, then the system stops sending requests after the first error is returned. If you run an association on 50 instances and set MaxError to 10%, then the system stops sending the request when the sixth error is received.
Executions that are already running an association when MaxErrors is reached are allowed to complete, but some of these executions may fail as well. If you need to ensure that there won't be more than max-errors failed executions, set MaxConcurrency to 1 so that executions proceed one at a time.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationRequest.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The name of the SSM document that contains the configuration information for the instance. You can specify Command or Automation documents.
You can specify AWS-predefined documents, documents you created, or a document that is shared with you from another account.
For SSM documents that are shared with you from other AWS accounts, you must specify the complete SSM document ARN, in the following format:
arn:partition:ssm:region:account-id:document/document-name
For example:
arn:aws:ssm:us-east-2:12345678912:document/My-Shared-Document
For AWS-predefined documents and SSM documents you created in your account, you only need to specify the document name. For example, AWS-ApplyPatchBaseline or My-Document.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationRequest.OutputLocation
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OutputLocation.
An Amazon S3 bucket where you want to store the output details of the request.

member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Parameters.
The parameters for the runtime configuration of the document.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationRequest.ScheduleExpression
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ScheduleExpression.
A cron expression when the association will be applied to the target(s).

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateAssociationRequest.Targets
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Targets.
The targets (either instances or tags) for the association. You must specify a value for Targets if you don't specify a value for InstanceId.

aws
amazon

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateDocumentRequest.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
Optional metadata that you assign to a resource. Tags enable you to categorize a resource in different ways, such as by purpose, owner, or environment. For example, you might want to tag an SSM document to identify the types of targets or the environment where it will run. In this case, you could specify the following key name/value pairs:
Key=OS,Value=Windows
Key=Environment,Value=Production
To add tags to an existing SSM document, use the AddTagsToResource action.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateDocumentRequest.TargetType
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TargetType.
Specify a target type to define the kinds of resources the document can run on. For example, to run a document on EC2 instances, specify the following value: /AWS::EC2::Instance. If you specify a value of '/' the document can run on all types of resources. If you don't specify a value, the document can't run on any resources. For a list of valid resource types, see AWS Resource Types Reference in the AWS CloudFormation User Guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateDocumentRequest.VersionName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property VersionName.
An optional field specifying the version of the artifact you are creating with the document. For example, "Release 12, Update 6". This value is unique across all versions of a document, and cannot be changed.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateMaintenanceWindowRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the CreateMaintenanceWindow operation. Creates a new maintenance window.
The value you specify for Duration determines the specific end time for the maintenance window based on the time it begins. No maintenance window tasks are permitted to start after the resulting endtime minus the number of hours you specify for Cutoff. For example, if the maintenance window starts at 3 PM, the duration is three hours, and the value you specify for Cutoff is one hour, no maintenance window tasks can start after 5 PM.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateMaintenanceWindowRequest.AllowUnassociatedTargets
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property AllowUnassociatedTargets.
Enables a maintenance window task to run on managed instances, even if you have not registered those instances as targets. If enabled, then you must specify the unregistered instances (by instance ID) when you register a task with the maintenance window.
If you don't enable this option, then you must specify previously-registered targets when you register a task with the maintenance window.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateMaintenanceWindowRequest.ClientToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ClientToken.
User-provided idempotency token.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateMaintenanceWindowRequest.Cutoff
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Cutoff.
The number of hours before the end of the maintenance window that Systems Manager stops scheduling new tasks for execution.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateMaintenanceWindowRequest.Description
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Description.
An optional description for the maintenance window. We recommend specifying a description to help you organize your maintenance windows.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateMaintenanceWindowRequest.Duration
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Duration.
The duration of the maintenance window in hours.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateMaintenanceWindowRequest.EndDate
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property EndDate.
The date and time, in ISO-8601 Extended format, for when you want the maintenance window to become inactive. EndDate allows you to set a date and time in the future when the maintenance window will no longer run.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateMaintenanceWindowRequest.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The name of the maintenance window.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateMaintenanceWindowRequest.Schedule
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Schedule.
The schedule of the maintenance window in the form of a cron or rate expression.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateMaintenanceWindowRequest.ScheduleTimezone
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ScheduleTimezone.
The time zone that the scheduled maintenance window executions are based on, in Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA) format. For example: "America/Los_Angeles", "etc/UTC", or "Asia/Seoul". For more information, see the Time Zone Database on the IANA website.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateMaintenanceWindowRequest.StartDate
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property StartDate.
The date and time, in ISO-8601 Extended format, for when you want the maintenance window to become active. StartDate allows you to delay activation of the maintenance window until the specified future date.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateMaintenanceWindowRequest.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
Optional metadata that you assign to a resource. Tags enable you to categorize a resource in different ways, such as by purpose, owner, or environment. For example, you might want to tag a maintenance window to identify the type of tasks it will run, the types of targets, and the environment it will run in. In this case, you could specify the following key name/value pairs:
Key=TaskType,Value=AgentUpdate
Key=OS,Value=Windows
Key=Environment,Value=Production
To add tags to an existing maintenance window, use the AddTagsToResource action.

member.summary: This is the response object from the CreateMaintenanceWindow operation.

member.summary:
Gets and sets the property WindowId.
The ID of the created maintenance window.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateOpsItemRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the CreateOpsItem operation. Creates a new OpsItem. You must have permission in AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) to create a new OpsItem. For more information, see Getting Started with OpsCenter in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide.
Operations engineers and IT professionals use OpsCenter to view, investigate, and remediate operational issues impacting the performance and health of their AWS resources. For more information, see AWS Systems Manager OpsCenter in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateOpsItemRequest.Description
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Description.
Information about the OpsItem.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateOpsItemRequest.Notifications
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Notifications.
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an SNS topic where notifications are sent when this OpsItem is edited or changed.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateOpsItemRequest.OperationalData
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OperationalData.
Operational data is custom data that provides useful reference details about the OpsItem. For example, you can specify log files, error strings, license keys, troubleshooting tips, or other relevant data. You enter operational data as key-value pairs. The key has a maximum length of 128 characters. The value has a maximum size of 20 KB.
Operational data keys can't begin with the following: amazon, aws, amzn, ssm, /amazon, /aws, /amzn, /ssm.
You can choose to make the data searchable by other users in the account or you can restrict search access. Searchable data means that all users with access to the OpsItem Overview page (as provided by the DescribeOpsItems API action) can view and search on the specified data. Operational data that is not searchable is only viewable by users who have access to the OpsItem (as provided by the GetOpsItem API action).
Use the /aws/resources key in OperationalData to specify a related resource in the request. Use the /aws/automations key in OperationalData to associate an Automation runbook with the OpsItem. To view AWS CLI example commands that use these keys, see Creating OpsItems Manually in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateOpsItemRequest.Priority
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Priority.
The importance of this OpsItem in relation to other OpsItems in the system.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateOpsItemRequest.RelatedOpsItems
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RelatedOpsItems.
One or more OpsItems that share something in common with the current OpsItems. For example, related OpsItems can include OpsItems with similar error messages, impacted resources, or statuses for the impacted resource.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateOpsItemRequest.Source
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Source.
The origin of the OpsItem, such as Amazon EC2 or AWS Systems Manager.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateOpsItemRequest.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
Optional metadata that you assign to a resource. You can restrict access to OpsItems by using an inline IAM policy that specifies tags. For more information, see Getting Started with OpsCenter in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide.
Tags use a key-value pair. For example:
Key=Department,Value=Finance
To add tags to an existing OpsItem, use the AddTagsToResource action.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateOpsItemRequest.Title
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Title.
A short heading that describes the nature of the OpsItem and the impacted resource.

member.summary: This is the response object from the CreateOpsItem operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateOpsItemResponse.OpsItemId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OpsItemId.
The ID of the OpsItem.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreatePatchBaselineRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the CreatePatchBaseline operation. Creates a patch baseline.
For information about valid key and value pairs in PatchFilters for each supported operating system type, see PatchFilter.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreatePatchBaselineRequest.ApprovalRules
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ApprovalRules.
A set of rules used to include patches in the baseline.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreatePatchBaselineRequest.ApprovedPatches
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ApprovedPatches.
A list of explicitly approved patches for the baseline.
For information about accepted formats for lists of approved patches and rejected patches, see Package Name Formats for Approved and Rejected Patch Lists in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreatePatchBaselineRequest.ApprovedPatchesComplianceLevel
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ApprovedPatchesComplianceLevel.
Defines the compliance level for approved patches. This means that if an approved patch is reported as missing, this is the severity of the compliance violation. The default value is UNSPECIFIED.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreatePatchBaselineRequest.ApprovedPatchesEnableNonSecurity
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ApprovedPatchesEnableNonSecurity.
Indicates whether the list of approved patches includes non-security updates that should be applied to the instances. The default value is 'false'. Applies to Linux instances only.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreatePatchBaselineRequest.ClientToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ClientToken.
User-provided idempotency token.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreatePatchBaselineRequest.Description
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Description.
A description of the patch baseline.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreatePatchBaselineRequest.GlobalFilters
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property GlobalFilters.
A set of global filters used to include patches in the baseline.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreatePatchBaselineRequest.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The name of the patch baseline.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreatePatchBaselineRequest.OperatingSystem
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OperatingSystem.
Defines the operating system the patch baseline applies to. The Default value is WINDOWS.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreatePatchBaselineRequest.RejectedPatches
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RejectedPatches.
A list of explicitly rejected patches for the baseline.
For information about accepted formats for lists of approved patches and rejected patches, see Package Name Formats for Approved and Rejected Patch Lists in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreatePatchBaselineRequest.RejectedPatchesAction
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RejectedPatchesAction.
The action for Patch Manager to take on patches included in the RejectedPackages list.
ALLOW_AS_DEPENDENCY: A package in the Rejected patches list is installed only if it is a dependency of another package. It is considered compliant with the patch baseline, and its status is reported as InstalledOther. This is the default action if no option is specified.
BLOCK: Packages in the RejectedPatches list, and packages that include them as dependencies, are not installed under any circumstances. If a package was installed before it was added to the Rejected patches list, it is considered non-compliant with the patch baseline, and its status is reported as InstalledRejected.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreatePatchBaselineRequest.Sources
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Sources.
Information about the patches to use to update the instances, including target operating systems and source repositories. Applies to Linux instances only.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreatePatchBaselineRequest.Tags
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Tags.
Optional metadata that you assign to a resource. Tags enable you to categorize a resource in different ways, such as by purpose, owner, or environment. For example, you might want to tag a patch baseline to identify the severity level of patches it specifies and the operating system family it applies to. In this case, you could specify the following key name/value pairs:
Key=PatchSeverity,Value=Critical
Key=OS,Value=Windows
To add tags to an existing patch baseline, use the AddTagsToResource action.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreatePatchBaselineResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the CreatePatchBaseline operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreatePatchBaselineResponse.BaselineId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property BaselineId.
The ID of the created patch baseline.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateResourceDataSyncRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the CreateResourceDataSync operation. Creates a resource data sync configuration to a single bucket in Amazon S3. This is an asynchronous operation that returns immediately. After a successful initial sync is completed, the system continuously syncs data to the Amazon S3 bucket. To check the status of the sync, use the ListResourceDataSync.
By default, data is not encrypted in Amazon S3. We strongly recommend that you enable encryption in Amazon S3 to ensure secure data storage. We also recommend that you secure access to the Amazon S3 bucket by creating a restrictive bucket policy. For more information, see Configuring Resource Data Sync for Inventory in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateResourceDataSyncRequest.S3Destination
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property S3Destination.
Amazon S3 configuration details for the sync.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.CreateResourceDataSyncRequest.SyncName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SyncName.
A name for the configuration.

member.summary: This is the response object from the CreateResourceDataSync operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.DeleteInventoryRequest
member.summary: Container for the parameters to the DeleteInventory operation. Delete a custom inventory type, or the data associated with a custom Inventory type. Deleting a custom inventory type is also referred to as deleting a custom inventory schema.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.DeleteInventoryRequest.ClientToken
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ClientToken.
User-provided idempotency token.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.DeleteInventoryRequest.DryRun
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property DryRun.
Use this option to view a summary of the deletion request without deleting any data or the data type. This option is useful when you only want to understand what will be deleted. Once you validate that the data to be deleted is what you intend to delete, you can run the same command without specifying the DryRun option.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.DeleteInventoryRequest.SchemaDeleteOption
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SchemaDeleteOption.
Use the SchemaDeleteOption to delete a custom inventory type (schema). If you don't choose this option, the system only deletes existing inventory data associated with the custom inventory type. Choose one of the following options:
DisableSchema: If you choose this option, the system ignores all inventory data for the specified version, and any earlier versions. To enable this schema again, you must call the PutInventory action for a version greater than the disabled version.
DeleteSchema: This option deletes the specified custom type from the Inventory service. You can recreate the schema later, if you want.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.DeleteInventoryRequest.TypeName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TypeName.
The name of the custom inventory type for which you want to delete either all previously collected data, or the inventory type itself.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.DeleteInventoryResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the DeleteInventory operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.DeleteInventoryResponse.DeletionId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property DeletionId.
Every DeleteInventory action is assigned a unique ID. This option returns a unique ID. You can use this ID to query the status of a delete operation. This option is useful for ensuring that a delete operation has completed before you begin other actions.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.DeleteInventoryResponse.DeletionSummary
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property DeletionSummary.
A summary of the delete operation. For more information about this summary, see Understanding the Delete Inventory Summary in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide.

member.summary:

The name of the inventory data type specified in the request.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.DescribeInstanceInformationRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the DescribeInstanceInformation operation. Describes one or more of your instances. You can use this to get information about instances like the operating system platform, the SSM Agent version (Linux), status etc. If you specify one or more instance IDs, it returns information for those instances. If you do not specify instance IDs, it returns information for all your instances. If you specify an instance ID that is not valid or an instance that you do not own, you receive an error.
The IamRole field for this API action is the Amazon Identity and Access Management (IAM) role assigned to on-premises instances. This call does not return the IAM role for Amazon EC2 instances.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.DescribeInstanceInformationRequest.Filters
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Filters.
One or more filters. Use a filter to return a more specific list of instances. You can filter on Amazon EC2 tag. Specify tags by using a key-value mapping.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.DescribeInstanceInformationRequest.InstanceInformationFilterList
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InstanceInformationFilterList.
This is a legacy method. We recommend that you don't use this method. Instead, use the InstanceInformationFilter action. The InstanceInformationFilter action enables you to return instance information by using tags that are specified as a key-value mapping.
If you do use this method, then you can't use the InstanceInformationFilter action. Using this method and the InstanceInformationFilter action causes an exception error.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.DescribeParametersRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the DescribeParameters operation. Get information about a parameter.
Request results are returned on a best-effort basis. If you specify MaxResults in the request, the response includes information up to the limit specified. The number of items returned, however, can be between zero and the value of MaxResults. If the service reaches an internal limit while processing the results, it stops the operation and returns the matching values up to that point and a NextToken. You can specify the NextToken in a subsequent call to get the next set of results.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.DescribePatchPropertiesRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the DescribePatchProperties operation. Lists the properties of available patches organized by product, product family, classification, severity, and other properties of available patches. You can use the reported properties in the filters you specify in requests for actions such as CreatePatchBaseline, UpdatePatchBaseline, DescribeAvailablePatches, and DescribePatchBaselines.
The following section lists the properties that can be used in filters for each major operating system type:
WINDOWS
Valid properties: PRODUCT, PRODUCT_FAMILY, CLASSIFICATION, MSRC_SEVERITY
AMAZON_LINUX
Valid properties: PRODUCT, CLASSIFICATION, SEVERITY
AMAZON_LINUX_2
Valid properties: PRODUCT, CLASSIFICATION, SEVERITY
UBUNTU
Valid properties: PRODUCT, PRIORITY
REDHAT_ENTERPRISE_LINUX
Valid properties: PRODUCT, CLASSIFICATION, SEVERITY
SUSE
Valid properties: PRODUCT, CLASSIFICATION, SEVERITY
CENTOS
Valid properties: PRODUCT, CLASSIFICATION, SEVERITY

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.DocumentKeyValuesFilter
member.summary:
One or more filters. Use a filter to return a more specific list of documents.
For keys, you can specify one or more tags that have been applied to a document.
Other valid values include Owner, Name, PlatformTypes, and DocumentType.
Note that only one Owner can be specified in a request. For example: Key=Owner,Values=Self.
If you use Name as a key, you can use a name prefix to return a list of documents. For example, in the AWS CLI, to return a list of all documents that begin with Te, run the following command:
aws ssm list-documents --filters Key=Name,Values=Te
If you specify more than two keys, only documents that are identified by all the tags are returned in the results. If you specify more than two values for a key, documents that are identified by any of the values are returned in the results.
To specify a custom key and value pair, use the format Key=tag:[tagName],Values=[valueName].
For example, if you created a Key called region and are using the AWS CLI to call the list-documents command:
aws ssm list-documents --filters Key=tag:region,Values=east,west Key=Owner,Values=Self

The name of the filter key.

member.summary:

member.summary:

member.summary:

member.summary: This is the response object from the GetCommandInvocation operation.

member.summary:

CloudWatch Logs information where Systems Manager sent the command output.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetCommandInvocationResponse.CommandId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property CommandId.
The parent command ID of the invocation plugin.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetCommandInvocationResponse.Comment
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Comment.
The comment text for the command.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetCommandInvocationResponse.DocumentName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property DocumentName.
The name of the document that was run. For example, AWS-RunShellScript.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetCommandInvocationResponse.DocumentVersion
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property DocumentVersion.
The SSM document version used in the request.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetCommandInvocationResponse.ExecutionElapsedTime
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExecutionElapsedTime.
Duration since ExecutionStartDateTime.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetCommandInvocationResponse.ExecutionEndDateTime
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExecutionEndDateTime.
The date and time the plugin was finished running. Date and time are written in ISO 8601 format. For example, June 7, 2017 is represented as 2017-06-7. The following sample AWS CLI command uses the InvokedAfter filter.
aws ssm list-commands --filters key=InvokedAfter,value=2017-06-07T00:00:00Z
If the plugin has not started to run, the string is empty.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetCommandInvocationResponse.ExecutionStartDateTime
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ExecutionStartDateTime.
The date and time the plugin started running. Date and time are written in ISO 8601 format. For example, June 7, 2017 is represented as 2017-06-7. The following sample AWS CLI command uses the InvokedBefore filter.
aws ssm list-commands --filters key=InvokedBefore,value=2017-06-07T00:00:00Z
If the plugin has not started to run, the string is empty.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetCommandInvocationResponse.InstanceId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InstanceId.
The ID of the managed instance targeted by the command. A managed instance can be an Amazon EC2 instance or an instance in your hybrid environment that is configured for Systems Manager.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetCommandInvocationResponse.PluginName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property PluginName.
The name of the plugin for which you want detailed results. For example, aws:RunShellScript is a plugin.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetCommandInvocationResponse.ResponseCode
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ResponseCode.
The error level response code for the plugin script. If the response code is -1, then the command has not started running on the instance, or it was not received by the instance.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetCommandInvocationResponse.StandardErrorContent
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property StandardErrorContent.
The first 8,000 characters written by the plugin to stderr. If the command has not finished running, then this string is empty.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetCommandInvocationResponse.StandardErrorUrl
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property StandardErrorUrl.
The URL for the complete text written by the plugin to stderr. If the command has not finished running, then this string is empty.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetCommandInvocationResponse.StandardOutputContent
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property StandardOutputContent.
The first 24,000 characters written by the plugin to stdout. If the command has not finished running, if ExecutionStatus is neither Succeeded nor Failed, then this string is empty.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetCommandInvocationResponse.StandardOutputUrl
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property StandardOutputUrl.
The URL for the complete text written by the plugin to stdout in Amazon S3. If an Amazon S3 bucket was not specified, then this string is empty.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetCommandInvocationResponse.Status
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Status.
The status of this invocation plugin. This status can be different than StatusDetails.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetCommandInvocationResponse.StatusDetails
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property StatusDetails.
A detailed status of the command execution for an invocation. StatusDetails includes more information than Status because it includes states resulting from error and concurrency control parameters. StatusDetails can show different results than Status. For more information about these statuses, see Understanding Command Statuses in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide. StatusDetails can be one of the following values:
Pending: The command has not been sent to the instance.
In Progress: The command has been sent to the instance but has not reached a terminal state.
Delayed: The system attempted to send the command to the target, but the target was not available. The instance might not be available because of network issues, the instance was stopped, etc. The system will try to deliver the command again.
Success: The command or plugin was run successfully. This is a terminal state.
Delivery Timed Out: The command was not delivered to the instance before the delivery timeout expired. Delivery timeouts do not count against the parent command's MaxErrors limit, but they do contribute to whether the parent command status is Success or Incomplete. This is a terminal state.
Execution Timed Out: The command started to run on the instance, but the execution was not complete before the timeout expired. Execution timeouts count against the MaxErrors limit of the parent command. This is a terminal state.
Failed: The command wasn't run successfully on the instance. For a plugin, this indicates that the result code was not zero. For a command invocation, this indicates that the result code for one or more plugins was not zero. Invocation failures count against the MaxErrors limit of the parent command. This is a terminal state.
Canceled: The command was terminated before it was completed. This is a terminal state.
Undeliverable: The command can't be delivered to the instance. The instance might not exist or might not be responding. Undeliverable invocations don't count against the parent command's MaxErrors limit and don't contribute to whether the parent command status is Success or Incomplete. This is a terminal state.
Terminated: The parent command exceeded its MaxErrors limit and subsequent command invocations were canceled by the system. This is a terminal state.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetParametersByPathRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the GetParametersByPath operation. Retrieve parameters in a specific hierarchy. For more information, see Working with Systems Manager Parameters in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide.
Request results are returned on a best-effort basis. If you specify MaxResults in the request, the response includes information up to the limit specified. The number of items returned, however, can be between zero and the value of MaxResults. If the service reaches an internal limit while processing the results, it stops the operation and returns the matching values up to that point and a NextToken. You can specify the NextToken in a subsequent call to get the next set of results.
This API action doesn't support filtering by tags.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetParametersByPathRequest.MaxResults
member.summary:

The maximum number of items to return for this call. The call also returns a token that you can specify in a subsequent call to get the next set of results.

member.summary:

A token to start the list. Use this token to get the next set of results.

member.summary:

Filters to limit the request results.
You can't filter using the parameter name.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetParametersByPathRequest.Path
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Path.
The hierarchy for the parameter. Hierarchies start with a forward slash (/) and end with the parameter name. A parameter name hierarchy can have a maximum of 15 levels. Here is an example of a hierarchy: /Finance/Prod/IAD/WinServ2016/license33

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetParametersByPathRequest.Recursive
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Recursive.
Retrieve all parameters within a hierarchy.
If a user has access to a path, then the user can access all levels of that path. For example, if a user has permission to access path /a, then the user can also access /a/b. Even if a user has explicitly been denied access in IAM for parameter /a/b, they can still call the GetParametersByPath API action recursively for /a and view /a/b.

Retrieve all parameters in a hierarchy with their value decrypted.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetServiceSettingRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the GetServiceSetting operation. ServiceSetting is an account-level setting for an AWS service. This setting defines how a user interacts with or uses a service or a feature of a service. For example, if an AWS service charges money to the account based on feature or service usage, then the AWS service team might create a default setting of "false". This means the user can't use this feature unless they change the setting to "true" and intentionally opt in for a paid feature.
Services map a SettingId object to a setting value. AWS services teams define the default value for a SettingId. You can't create a new SettingId, but you can overwrite the default value if you have the ssm:UpdateServiceSetting permission for the setting. Use the UpdateServiceSetting API action to change the default setting. Or use the ResetServiceSetting to change the value back to the original value defined by the AWS service team.
Query the current service setting for the account.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.GetServiceSettingRequest.SettingId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SettingId.
The ID of the service setting to get.

member.summary: The query result body of the GetServiceSetting API action.

member.summary:

The query result of the current service setting.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchState
member.summary: Defines the high-level patch compliance state for a managed instance, providing information about the number of installed, missing, not applicable, and failed patches along with metadata about the operation when this information was gathered for the instance.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchState.BaselineId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property BaselineId.
The ID of the patch baseline used to patch the instance.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchState.FailedCount
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property FailedCount.
The number of patches from the patch baseline that were attempted to be installed during the last patching operation, but failed to install.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchState.InstalledCount
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InstalledCount.
The number of patches from the patch baseline that are installed on the instance.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchState.InstalledOtherCount
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InstalledOtherCount.
The number of patches not specified in the patch baseline that are installed on the instance.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchState.InstalledRejectedCount
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InstalledRejectedCount.
The number of instances with patches installed that are specified in a RejectedPatches list. Patches with a status of InstalledRejected were typically installed before they were added to a RejectedPatches list.
If ALLOW_AS_DEPENDENCY is the specified option for RejectedPatchesAction, the value of InstalledRejectedCount will always be 0 (zero).

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchState.InstallOverrideList
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InstallOverrideList.
An https URL or an Amazon S3 path-style URL to a list of patches to be installed. This patch installation list, which you maintain in an Amazon S3 bucket in YAML format and specify in the SSM document AWS-RunPatchBaseline, overrides the patches specified by the default patch baseline.
For more information about the InstallOverrideList parameter, see About the SSM Document AWS-RunPatchBaseline in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchState.InstanceId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InstanceId.
The ID of the managed instance the high-level patch compliance information was collected for.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchState.MissingCount
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property MissingCount.
The number of patches from the patch baseline that are applicable for the instance but aren't currently installed.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchState.NotApplicableCount
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property NotApplicableCount.
The number of patches from the patch baseline that aren't applicable for the instance and therefore aren't installed on the instance. This number may be truncated if the list of patch names is very large. The number of patches beyond this limit are reported in UnreportedNotApplicableCount.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchState.Operation
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Operation.
The type of patching operation that was performed: SCAN (assess patch compliance state) or INSTALL (install missing patches).

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchState.OperationEndTime
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OperationEndTime.
The time the most recent patching operation completed on the instance.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchState.OperationStartTime
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OperationStartTime.
The time the most recent patching operation was started on the instance.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchState.OwnerInformation
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property OwnerInformation.
Placeholder information. This field will always be empty in the current release of the service.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchState.PatchGroup
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property PatchGroup.
The name of the patch group the managed instance belongs to.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchState.SnapshotId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SnapshotId.
The ID of the patch baseline snapshot used during the patching operation when this compliance data was collected.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchState.UnreportedNotApplicableCount
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property UnreportedNotApplicableCount.
The number of patches beyond the supported limit of NotApplicableCount that are not reported by name to Systems Manager Inventory.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchStateFilter
member.summary: Defines a filter used in DescribeInstancePatchStatesForPatchGroup used to scope down the information returned by the API.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchStateFilter.Key
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Key.
The key for the filter. Supported values are FailedCount, InstalledCount, InstalledOtherCount, MissingCount and NotApplicableCount.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchStateFilter.Type
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Type.
The type of comparison that should be performed for the value: Equal, NotEqual, LessThan or GreaterThan.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InstancePatchStateFilter.Values
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Values.
The value for the filter, must be an integer greater than or equal to 0.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryAggregator
member.summary: Specifies the inventory type and attribute for the aggregation execution.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryAggregator.Aggregators
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Aggregators.
Nested aggregators to further refine aggregation for an inventory type.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryAggregator.Expression
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Expression.
The inventory type and attribute name for aggregation.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryAggregator.Groups
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Groups.
A user-defined set of one or more filters on which to aggregate inventory data. Groups return a count of resources that match and don't match the specified criteria.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryDeletionStatusItem
member.summary: Status information returned by the DeleteInventory action.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryDeletionStatusItem.DeletionId
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property DeletionId.
The deletion ID returned by the DeleteInventory action.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryDeletionStatusItem.DeletionStartTime
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property DeletionStartTime.
The UTC timestamp when the delete operation started.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryDeletionStatusItem.DeletionSummary
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property DeletionSummary.
Information about the delete operation. For more information about this summary, see Understanding the Delete Inventory Summary in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryDeletionStatusItem.LastStatus
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property LastStatus.
The status of the operation. Possible values are InProgress and Complete.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryDeletionStatusItem.LastStatusMessage
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property LastStatusMessage.
Information about the status.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryDeletionStatusItem.LastStatusUpdateTime
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property LastStatusUpdateTime.
The UTC timestamp of when the last status report.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryDeletionStatusItem.TypeName
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TypeName.
The name of the inventory data type.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryDeletionSummary
member.summary: Information about the delete operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryDeletionSummary.RemainingCount
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RemainingCount.
Remaining number of items to delete.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryDeletionSummary.SummaryItems
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property SummaryItems.
A list of counts and versions for deleted items.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryDeletionSummary.TotalCount
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property TotalCount.
The total number of items to delete. This count does not change during the delete operation.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryDeletionSummaryItem
member.summary: Either a count, remaining count, or a version number in a delete inventory summary.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryDeletionSummaryItem.Count
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Count.
A count of the number of deleted items.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryDeletionSummaryItem.RemainingCount
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property RemainingCount.
The remaining number of items to delete.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryDeletionSummaryItem.Version
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Version.
The inventory type version.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryGroup

member.summary:

Filters define the criteria for the group. The matchingCount field displays the number of resources that match the criteria. The notMatchingCount field displays the number of resources that don't match the criteria.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryGroup.Name
member.summary:

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryItem.ContentHash
member.summary:

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.InventoryItem.TypeName
member.summary:

The name of the inventory type. Default inventory item type names start with AWS. Custom inventory type names will start with Custom. Default inventory item types include the following: AWS:AWSComponent, AWS:Application, AWS:InstanceInformation, AWS:Network, and AWS:WindowsUpdate.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.LabelParameterVersionRequest
member.summary:
Container for the parameters to the LabelParameterVersion operation. A parameter label is a user-defined alias to help you manage different versions of a parameter. When you modify a parameter, Systems Manager automatically saves a new version and increments the version number by one. A label can help you remember the purpose of a parameter when there are multiple versions.
Parameter labels have the following requirements and restrictions.
A version of a parameter can have a maximum of 10 labels.
You can't attach the same label to different versions of the same parameter. For example, if version 1 has the label Production, then you can't attach Production to version 2.
You can move a label from one version of a parameter to another.
You can't create a label when you create a new parameter. You must attach a label to a specific version of a parameter.
You can't delete a parameter label. If you no longer want to use a parameter label, then you must move it to a different version of a parameter.
A label can have a maximum of 100 characters.
Labels can contain letters (case sensitive), numbers, periods (.), hyphens (-), or underscores (_).
Labels can't begin with a number, "aws," or "ssm" (not case sensitive). If a label fails to meet these requirements, then the label is not associated with a parameter and the system displays it in the list of InvalidLabels.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.LabelParameterVersionRequest.Labels
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Labels.
One or more labels to attach to the specified parameter version.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.LabelParameterVersionRequest.Name
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property Name.
The parameter name on which you want to attach one or more labels.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.LabelParameterVersionRequest.ParameterVersion
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ParameterVersion.
The specific version of the parameter on which you want to attach one or more labels. If no version is specified, the system attaches the label to the latest version.

member.name: T:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.LabelParameterVersionResponse
member.summary: This is the response object from the LabelParameterVersion operation.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.LabelParameterVersionResponse.InvalidLabels
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property InvalidLabels.
The label does not meet the requirements. For information about parameter label requirements, see Labeling Parameters in the AWS Systems Manager User Guide.

member.name: P:Amazon.SimpleSystemsManagement.Model.LabelParameterVersionResponse.ParameterVersion
member.summary:
Gets and sets the property ParameterVersion.
The version of the parameter that has been labeled.

member.summary: Container for the parameters to the ListCommandInvocations operation. An invocation is copy of a command sent to a specific instance. A command can apply to one or more instances. A command invocation applies to one instance. For example, if a user runs SendCommand against three instances, then a command invocation is created for each requested instance ID. ListCommandInvocations provide status about command execution.
